subject: object-updater: add concurrent updates
messages:
[{'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-05 00:14:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-06-05 04:55:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

thanks sam!'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-05 11:34:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-05 20:22:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-05 20:22:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-05 22:02:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-06 21:05:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Some benchmark numbers: I had a machine with ~22M async_pendings on it; the number was decreasing by about 2M/week. With this patch, the same number of worker processes (one per disk, twelve total), and concurrency=64, it's processed about 3M in the last day, or 21M/week. That's a pretty good improvement."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-08 11:46:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

I'm still concerned about the change to meaning of 'concurrency' because apart from an op seeing fewer processes than expected, performance might also degrade after swift upgrade e.g. if four processes becomes one process with four threads.

It's a pain - the only way I can see to move towards consistent conf options without changing the meaning of concurrency is to introduce a new option name such as threads_per_worker, make that the preferred option in all daemons and deprecate concurrency everywhere.

I'm not opposed to changing the meaning of concurrency here but I would like it more widely discussed before doing so."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-08 18:25:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-08 18:25:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-08 18:35:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I can see the need for a little more discussion of the config changes. I'll put an item on the next Swift meeting's agenda."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-13 22:37:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-06-13 23:52:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(4 comments)

I think I like it... but I'd want some sort of recommendation on what you ought to do before upgrading...

What config do I need to push out before upgrading so I can get through the upgrade without setting off pagers because either async pendings or handoff partitions are climbing quickly?"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-14 00:30:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

I'll work on an upgrade note."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-14 01:04:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-06-14 16:51:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-05 00:14:43.000000000', 'message': 'object-updater: add concurrent updates

The object updater now supports two configuration settings:
"concurrency" and "updater_workers". The latter controls how many
worker processes are spawned, while the former controls how many
concurrent container updates are performed by each worker
process. This should speed the processing of async_pendings.

There is a change to the semantics of the configuration
options. Previously, "concurrency" controlled the number of worker
processes spawned, and "updater_workers" did not exist. I switched the
meanings for consistency with other configuration options. In the
object reconstructor, object replicator, object server, object
expirer, container replicator, container server, account replicator,
account server, and account reaper, "concurrency" refers to the number
of concurrent tasks performed within one process (for reference, the
container updater and object auditor use "concurrency" to mean number
of processes).

On upgrade, each node will still handle async updates N-at-a-time, but
will do so using only one process instead of N.

Change-Id: I17e18088e61f664e1b9942d66423666d0cae1689

On upgrade, each node will still handle async updates N-at-a-time, but
will do so using only one process instead of N.

UpgradeImpact

The object updater now supports two configuration settings:
"concurrency" and "updater_workers". The latter controls how many
worker processes are spawned, while the former controls how many
concurrent container updates are performed by each worker
process. This should speed the processing of async_pendings.

There is a change to the semantics of the configuration
options. Previously, "concurrency" controlled the number of worker
processes spawned, and "updater_workers" did not exist. I switched the
meanings for consistency with other configuration options. In the
object reconstructor, object replicator, object server, object
expirer, container replicator, container server, account replicator,
account server, and account reaper, "concurrency" refers to the number
of concurrent tasks performed within one process (for reference, the
container updater and object auditor use "concurrency" to mean number
of processes).

On upgrade, a node configured with concurrency=N will still handle
async updates N-at-a-time, but will do so using only one process
instead of N.

UpgradeImpact

Change-Id: I17e18088e61f664e1b9942d66423666d0cae1689
'}, {'created': '2018-06-14 01:04:36.000000000', 'message': 'object-updater: add concurrent updates

The object updater now supports two configuration settings:
"concurrency" and "updater_workers". The latter controls how many
worker processes are spawned, while the former controls how many
concurrent container updates are performed by each worker
process. This should speed the processing of async_pendings.

There is a change to the semantics of the configuration
options. Previously, "concurrency" controlled the number of worker
processes spawned, and "updater_workers" did not exist. I switched the
meanings for consistency with other configuration options. In the
object reconstructor, object replicator, object server, object
expirer, container replicator, container server, account replicator,
account server, and account reaper, "concurrency" refers to the number
of concurrent tasks performed within one process (for reference, the
container updater and object auditor use "concurrency" to mean number
of processes).

On upgrade, a node configured with concurrency=N will still handle
async updates N-at-a-time, but will do so using only one process
instead of N.

UpgradeImpact:

If you have a config file like this:

    [object-updater]
    concurrency = <N>

and you want to take advantage of faster updates, then do this:

    [object-updater]
    concurrency = 8  # the default; you can omit this line
    updater_workers = <N>

If you want updates to be processed exactly as before, do this:

    [object-updater]
    concurrency = 1
    updater_workers = <N>

Change-Id: I17e18088e61f664e1b9942d66423666d0cae1689
'}]
commit_message:
object-updater: add concurrent updates

The object updater now supports two configuration settings:
"concurrency" and "updater_workers". The latter controls how many
worker processes are spawned, while the former controls how many
concurrent container updates are performed by each worker
process. This should speed the processing of async_pendings.

There is a change to the semantics of the configuration
options. Previously, "concurrency" controlled the number of worker
processes spawned, and "updater_workers" did not exist. I switched the
meanings for consistency with other configuration options. In the
object reconstructor, object replicator, object server, object
expirer, container replicator, container server, account replicator,
account server, and account reaper, "concurrency" refers to the number
of concurrent tasks performed within one process (for reference, the
container updater and object auditor use "concurrency" to mean number
of processes).

On upgrade, a node configured with concurrency=N will still handle
async updates N-at-a-time, but will do so using only one process
instead of N.

UpgradeImpact:

If you have a config file like this:

    [object-updater]
    concurrency = <N>

and you want to take advantage of faster updates, then do this:

    [object-updater]
    concurrency = 8  # the default; you can omit this line
    updater_workers = <N>

If you want updates to be processed exactly as before, do this:

    [object-updater]
    concurrency = 1
    updater_workers = <N>

Change-Id: I17e18088e61f664e1b9942d66423666d0cae1689

commit_message:
Add xenial node for vexxhost kata testing

Kata CI doesn't currently work on Bionic due to lack of docker-ce
packages for bionic. Lets just use xenial for now which they already
use.

Change-Id: Ief0f20c2f1b42a5c23ed05f7185c58700f65b06e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-11 16:54:37.000000000', 'message': 'Throw an error on conflicting microversion config

If we pull an implied default microversion from the api_version, but an
explicit default_microversion has been given we have no idea what the
user wants us to do. Throw an error.

Change-Id: Id095df356a563bec90931b70f6d2c9cb4affc098
'}]
commit_message:
Throw an error on conflicting microversion config

If we pull an implied default microversion from the api_version, but an
explicit default_microversion has been given we have no idea what the
user wants us to do. Throw an error.

Change-Id: Id095df356a563bec90931b70f6d2c9cb4affc098

commit_message:
Rename service_key to service_type

Back in the early days there wasn't clear terminology so
os-client-config used the term 'service_key' internally to mean
"official service-type". But we have service-types-authority now and
it's understood that a service has a service-type. Use the word in the
code so that things aren't confusing.

Change-Id: Ia6484e3ee555c578e264c1e47c1817bbfe4d7925

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-30 14:24:42.000000000', 'message': 'Pass default_microversion to adapter constructor

Based on discussion with the API-SIG, we determined that if someone sets
*_api_version or OS_*_API_VERSION to a value that looks like a
microversion, we should pass it to default_microversion in addition to
using it for major version discovery.

Update the docs to reflect the microversion story (and to remove shade
references)

Set a default for baremetal_default_microversion to 1.6, which is the
default microversion currently being set manually by the ironic code.

Change-Id: Iad7194dc9e933660c0d0df9130c51d505dda50cb

that microversion might not be available on the cloud in question. Throw
an error in such cases.

microversion, we should pass it to default_microversion in addition to
using it for major version discovery.

Update the docs to reflect the microversion story (and to remove shade
references)

Set a default for baremetal_default_microversion to 1.6, which is the
default microversion currently being set manually by the ironic code.

Also, throw an error on missing support for default microversion

We've given the user the ability to set a default microversion. However,
that microversion might not be available on the cloud in question. Throw
an error in such cases.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/568640
Change-Id: Iad7194dc9e933660c0d0df9130c51d505dda50cb

commit_message:
Pass default_microversion to adapter constructor

Based on discussion with the API-SIG, we determined that if someone sets
*_api_version or OS_*_API_VERSION to a value that looks like a
microversion, we should pass it to default_microversion in addition to
using it for major version discovery.

Update the docs to reflect the microversion story (and to remove shade
references)

Also, throw an error on missing support for default microversion

We've given the user the ability to set a default microversion. However,
that microversion might not be available on the cloud in question. Throw
an error in such cases.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/568640
Change-Id: Iad7194dc9e933660c0d0df9130c51d505dda50cb

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-04 13:37:47.000000000', 'message': 'snmp: listen on ctrlplane

Ceilometer uses the ctrlplane to poll snmpd on each
ironic node.

43155ed1462a8e27c9efdbb345bfc5832c50bd2f have restrict snmpd
to the internal_api subnet which breaks Ceilometer that use the
ctrlplane subnet.

This change puts the ctrlplane as default for snmpd.

Closes-bug: #1775001
Change-Id: Ia310e02d30ce037c2cc7fec146f27fbd0f8055f4
'}]
commit_message:
snmp: listen on ctrlplane

Ceilometer uses the ctrlplane to poll snmpd on each
ironic node.

43155ed1462a8e27c9efdbb345bfc5832c50bd2f have restrict snmpd
to the internal_api subnet which breaks Ceilometer that use the
ctrlplane subnet.

This change puts the ctrlplane as default for snmpd.

Closes-bug: #1775001
Change-Id: Ia310e02d30ce037c2cc7fec146f27fbd0f8055f4

commit_message:
NetApp ONTAP: Fix delete-share for vsadmin users

qos- APIs are unavailable to vsadmin users. Fix the
code in the delete share flow to prevent failing on
being unable to execute the qos-get-iter call.

Change-Id: If9ce7c840fc968824d53002eaaea082e28631178
Closes-Bug: 1765420

commit_message:
Mock log output from DataCore drivers

The large amount of error logging output from the DataCore API
tests is causing issues that result in hitting an error with
stestr. This logging output is not needed during unit testing,
so this just mocks out the logger to prevent them from happening.

Change-Id: Ie9c3c6e0ee0826d4508599125155b6aceb64d369
Closes-bug: #1775707

commit_message:
Allow using spaces for primary common name in SSL certificates

The common name is used as a file name inside the HAproxy
configuration file.  However, a common name can include spaces
and it will result in a configuration file that simply doesn't
work because of the spaces.

The patch changes the functionality so that it instead creates
a SHA1 hash of the certificate and uses that as the file name
to avoid those issues.

Change-Id: I039ed0b40df8b72a1238f8896548fe77086c530c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-07 00:12:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix use of pbr version release

The "release" member of pbr's VersionInfo
class was removed when [1] introduced
Semantic Versioning. Fix the sole usage of
this member and associated pylint error E1101:

["Instance of 'VersionInfo' has no 'release' member",
"return version.version_info.release"]

[1] I482e07cce9b65df452d5b9af4c73960df68a141e

Change-Id: Ia2a241b5ac2ddca29effe3e83df151bec6a76cba
'}]
commit_message:
Fix use of pbr version release

The "release" member of pbr's VersionInfo
class was removed when [1] introduced
Semantic Versioning. Fix the sole usage of
this member and associated pylint error E1101:

["Instance of 'VersionInfo' has no 'release' member",
"return version.version_info.release"]

[1] I482e07cce9b65df452d5b9af4c73960df68a141e

Change-Id: Ia2a241b5ac2ddca29effe3e83df151bec6a76cba

commit_message:
Set update_containers for containerized_undercloud

This is needed by I62a4b03538d26083a0ba4ce0b2e7a5b0c456134d so that
a containerized undercloud can be run with the updated packages, just
like the overcloud.

Change-Id: Ifacc7b1940a607bb61527e988c0ef654cd123438
Depends-On: I62a4b03538d26083a0ba4ce0b2e7a5b0c456134d

commit_message:
remove CORE and L3 from neutron_lib.constants

The CORE and L3 service type name constants are defined in both
neutron_lib.constants and neutron_lib.plugin.constants. The later is
the desired location for them and this patch formalizes that by
removing them from the former.

Change-Id: I5cbe779b401e5214f414ab1c732867fdd4d75651

commit_message:
Add BlacklistedHostnames stack output

The BacklistedHostnames stack output will be used as input into the
config-download-deploy workflow so that the hostnames can be excluded
from the Ansible deployment with config-download.

Change-Id: I4705be446756869ba3d04fc59daffa4d4748e12c

commit_message:
Add bandit to pep8 gate

Neutron uses bandit to detect security issues. This patch adds bandit
to the pep8 gate to automatically lint for security issues in
python-neutronclient.

Change-Id: Ifd8caf65cc89e7d6d6ebc8f58539741cfbab839b

commit_message:
Refactor get-occ-config.sh

* Add $ to to eval hosts to get proper dereference
* Add quatas around eval
* Replace let with ((i++))

Change-Id: I5dbb6ef16598905b6d3bbb9efc448e0b45cbe099
(cherry picked from commit 961f7315f31e4ee68668406a6a67485fef738eae)

commit_message:
Introduce nlbaas shim driver layer for APIv2

Also includes bringing over the neutron lbaas logging noop driver as an
example of what needs to be done.

Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Partial-Bug: #1596658
Change-Id: Ie3f5b5bbd94c2c9af8fc4e04537545c1c23ec771

commit_message:
Pass context from API controllers to handler

The neutron lbaas drivers will need information from the context so we
need to pass that down to the handler from the Octavia controllers.

Change-Id: Ic35887f098638070fe4f236641f204a790b9865a

messages:
[{'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2018-01-30 08:34:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2018-01-30 11:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-01-30 16:06:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't know that the plugin is ready for this.
It will also need to go into a new non-voting gate job that should be legacy free (no gate hook)."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-01-30 16:07:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, at this point the plugin is targeting the v2 API and not the v1  API that the changes below modify.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-01-31 02:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Yes, can we use v2 api plugin in v1 jobs?'}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2018-02-01 06:50:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Hengqing, @Michael, I am confused. neutron-lbaas is deprecated, the jobs defined in octavia are based on v1 api and neutron-lbaas is on v2, Which jobs i use in order to consume the octavia tempest plugin?'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-02-09 16:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Chandan,
I understand the versioning situation is a bit confusing. I have put together an FAQ that might help with the version confusion: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/LBaaS/Deprecation#Neutron-lbaas_vs._LBaaS_v2_API_vs._Octavia_vs._Octavia_v2_API

That said, I have created a patch that shows how we can pull in the octavia-tempest-plugin tests: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541002/

With Zuul v3 this is pretty easy to do.

However, the octavia-tempest-plugin tests need work. We are focusing to clean these up now. Unfortunately we lost the developer that was working on the octavia-tempest-plugin, but we are shifting focus to help there.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-06-14 18:20:10.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This has been completed in other patches for the octavia-tempest-plugin.'}]

'}]

You can see this in action here: http://logs.openstack.org/54/549654/35/check/octavia-grenade/fd5303f/logs/screen-o-hm.txt.gz#_Jun_06_06_57_48_337890'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-06-06 15:49:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Frankly, 99.99999% of the time that code shouldn't be running anyway. It is just DB overhead unless the dumb event streamer is enabled."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-06-14 18:16:37.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

I guess the zombie patch takes care of this.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/561369/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-06 08:46:00.000000000', 'message': 'Fix stats update when missing listener in DB

If a stats update is triggered by a health message, and the message
includes a listener that is not in the db (probably it was just
deleted?) then it would explode when looking up the lb_id to report the
LB stats. We can assume that from the amphora_id, so do that instead.

Yes, this breaks the "multi-lb per amp" case, but we don't do that and
we never should, so let's just do what we can here?

Change-Id: Ia29cc4c1809941fd08ab7186f7d6e5c0100e1aee
'}]
commit_message:
Fix stats update when missing listener in DB

If a stats update is triggered by a health message, and the message
includes a listener that is not in the db (probably it was just
deleted?) then it would explode when looking up the lb_id to report the
LB stats. We can assume that from the amphora_id, so do that instead.

Yes, this breaks the "multi-lb per amp" case, but we don't do that and
we never should, so let's just do what we can here?

Change-Id: Ia29cc4c1809941fd08ab7186f7d6e5c0100e1aee

commit_message:
Sort the children in the output of service list

Currently when you do a "service list" the services are
correctly sorted, but the children are not. This sorts the
children.

commit_message:
Add grenade support

Zuul v3 does not yet offer native grenade base jobs. Workaround it by
creating a legacy grenade-devstack-octavia playbook.

Change-Id: Ib81557ee75ff2ea365ca8403dcfe6e6724657f75

subject: Add element and flag to disable DHCP on amp images
messages:
[{'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2017-11-16 14:08:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-11-16 14:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2017-11-16 16:33:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

This is dirty.  We are manipulating system scripts to override what cloudinit is doing.  Why don't we setup nova/cloudinit/neutron for success?
Not only will you run into problems with cloudinit overriding this, but cloudinit does the platform/release conversion for us.
http://cloudinit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/topics/network-config-format-v2.html#common-properties-for-all-device-types"}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2017-11-19 13:42:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> This is dirty.  We are manipulating system scripts to override what
 > cloudinit is doing.  Why don't we setup nova/cloudinit/neutron for
 > success?
 > Not only will you run into problems with cloudinit overriding this,
 > but cloudinit does the platform/release conversion for us.
 > http://cloudinit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/topics/network-config-format-v2.html#common-properties-for-all-device-types

+1"}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2017-12-05 09:25:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm not sure if I have logs from before I applied this patch to my amps (it was a long time ago) but I can tell you that this for sure does work, and at least on my amps it is not overwritten by cloud-init -- in fact, it was locking up on DHCP before cloud-init even ran IIRC (really wish I had the logs)."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2017-12-05 09:26:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

^^ In regards to my comment, I'm referring to Patchset 1 (my code). I haven't tested the code in Patchset 2. I am only using CentOS, and we are stuck on a pretty old version of cloud-init too."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-06 02:35:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-06 03:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-06 08:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-06 10:52:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-06 13:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2017-12-13 20:13:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-13 21:35:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-13 21:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2017-12-13 22:15:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Still -1 this. As Adam found, cloud-init overwrites this.
We need to create a better way to achieve the goals.
Per the weekly meeting, we need stories that describe the use cases to work from.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-14 07:40:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Cloud init will not overwrite since networking is already disabled.
If it's a fresh image build with this, there won't be any problem."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2017-12-14 16:51:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@Hengqing Hu Umm, I don't know what you mean that networking is disabled.  rm_work confirmed my statement yesterday during the meeting that he is seeing the files overwriten in his deployment.

It was also reported that cloud-init still dhcps even if there is only an ipv6 subnet with slaac enabled. That is not the case. Please provide the requested logs if you think you are seeing that."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-15 02:58:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2017-12-15 03:00:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

It was also reported that cloud-init still dhcps even if there is only an ipv6 subnet with slaac enabled. 

That's the exactly problem, so if it tries to dhcp and there is no dhcp server, it will make the boot time up to 3 minutes.

https://docs.openstack.org/ocata/networking-guide/config-ipv6.html

N/S 	slaac 	Off 	1,0,0 	Guest instance obtains IPv6 address from non-OpenStack router using SLAAC."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-03-09 08:52:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

So, actually this is still a problem for me, and I am stuck running a simple version of this patch in my downstream CI because this is necessary for my cloud to work. Amps sit for an insanely long time during boot without it, as we don't have DHCP.

Are you blocking this because you don't want it, or because you think it doesn't solve his particular problem? Because it does solve mine..."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-03-09 08:55:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-03-09 08:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-03-09 15:08:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26553, 'date': '2018-03-12 01:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

Mmm maybe it's not so cleanly for 3 reasons:
1. Code: Eth0 isn't always the exact Nic/vNic's name. For example, it may be named eno1 on CentOS 7.* or ens***.
2. Design：As a Cloud-Management platform, it's not recommended to interferer with Cloud-business's configuration file.
3. Deploy：In order to put the new configuration into effect, network service should be reloaded, and the reload-command is different based on different OS, e.g. 'systemctl restart network.service' on CentOS7.*  KDE."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-03-12 10:07:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> Mmm maybe it's not so cleanly for 3 reasons:
 > 1. Code: Eth0 isn't always the exact Nic/vNic's name. For example,
 > it may be named eno1 on CentOS 7.* or ens***.
Actually, that is taken care of in the diskimage-build script, where we set biosdevname=0 so it will actually be eth0.
 > 2. Design：As a Cloud-Management platform, it's not recommended to
 > interferer with Cloud-business's configuration file.
I'm not sure about this point -- this is for an amphora image which is specifically used only by Octavia service to create its special purpose VMs, AND it's a configuration option whether to do this or not, so the deployer chooses.
 > 3. Deploy：In order to put the new configuration into effect,
 > network service should be reloaded, and the reload-command is
 > different based on different OS, e.g. 'systemctl restart
 > network.service' on CentOS7.*  KDE.
This happens during the image build, so there is no need to restart anything -- this changes the config before the first boot even happens."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-03-12 10:09:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Let me try this comment again, as the formatting made it difficult to read.

 > Mmm maybe it's not so cleanly for 3 reasons:
 > 1. Code: Eth0 isn't always the exact Nic/vNic's name. For example,
 > it may be named eno1 on CentOS 7.* or ens***.

Actually, that is taken care of in the diskimage-build script, where we set biosdevname=0 so it will actually be eth0.

 > 2. Design：As a Cloud-Management platform, it's not recommended to
 > interferer with Cloud-business's configuration file.

I'm not sure about this point -- this is for an amphora image which is specifically used only by Octavia service to create its special purpose VMs, AND it's a configuration option whether to do this or not, so the deployer chooses.

 > 3. Deploy：In order to put the new configuration into effect,
 > network service should be reloaded, and the reload-command is
 > different based on different OS, e.g. 'systemctl restart
 > network.service' on CentOS7.*  KDE.

This happens during the image build, so there is no need to restart anything -- this changes the config before the first boot even happens."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-03-17 08:22:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> Let me try this comment again, as the formatting made it difficult
 > to read.
 > 
 > > Mmm maybe it's not so cleanly for 3 reasons:
 > > 1. Code: Eth0 isn't always the exact Nic/vNic's name. For
 > example,
 > > it may be named eno1 on CentOS 7.* or ens***.
 > 
 > Actually, that is taken care of in the diskimage-build script,
 > where we set biosdevname=0 so it will actually be eth0.
 > 
 > > 2. Design：As a Cloud-Management platform, it's not recommended to
 > > interferer with Cloud-business's configuration file.
 > 
 > I'm not sure about this point -- this is for an amphora image which
 > is specifically used only by Octavia service to create its special
 > purpose VMs, AND it's a configuration option whether to do this or
 > not, so the deployer chooses.
 > 
 > > 3. Deploy：In order to put the new configuration into effect,
 > > network service should be reloaded, and the reload-command is
 > > different based on different OS, e.g. 'systemctl restart
 > > network.service' on CentOS7.*  KDE.
 > 
 > This happens during the image build, so there is no need to restart
 > anything -- this changes the config before the first boot even
 > happens.

+1"}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-03-19 23:58:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

I still stand that this is the wrong approach and we need to get to the root of the issue.
The comment from Long is correct, "eth" cannot be assumed here.
I still want to see a story created for this that describes the exact case and includes logs and net/subnet shows output.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-05-09 22:24:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

With `biosdevname=0` I don't understand how it could be something besides `eth`? That's what that flag does..."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-05-09 22:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2018-05-27 17:58:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-06-14 17:55:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Nir: no, it works fine.

BUT, looks like centos fixed whatever the ordering issue was around cloud-init/dhcp, so it works properly now without this.'}]

commit_message:
remove publish-openstack-python-tarball

zmq-event-publisher isn't a python project, so does not need a python
artifact publishing job.

tripleo-upgrade should use the branch version of the tarball job
instead.

Change-Id: I4d5af9d0212de8fb60b5d1d1beccb04469ec549c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

entry points for networking-ovn. The idea is to have a command
for the migration tool so that we can better productize it.

NOTE: As this patch is adding new binaries, the tripleo job will
fail while trying to build the RPM as the new files are not present
in the spec. This is a chicken-egg problem as we can't merge the
spec file without this patch so I'm making the job non-voting for
now.

Change-Id: I265baabdc80a3df9df07d7c33d850184b432d9d6
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Add the tool to update the networks MTU to entry points

This patch adds the tool to update the networks MTU to the
entry points for networking-ovn. The idea is to have a command
for the migration tool so that we can better productize it.

NOTE: As this patch is adding new binaries, the tripleo job will
fail while trying to build the RPM as the new files are not present
in the spec. This is a chicken-egg problem as we can't merge the
spec file without this patch so I'm making the job non-voting for
now.

Change-Id: I265baabdc80a3df9df07d7c33d850184b432d9d6
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-07 21:51:33.000000000', 'message': 'update shell tests to not rely on the serialization order of a dict

Under python 3 with ordering randomized we cannot depend on the JSON
output matching exactly. Instead we de-serialize the data structure
that was written and compare the structures, which will always match.

Change-Id: I134b62413a7cde25f3efda6a2452c1e3d11d41d0
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
update shell tests to not rely on the serialization order of a dict

Under python 3 with ordering randomized we cannot depend on the JSON
output matching exactly. Instead we de-serialize the data structure
that was written and compare the structures, which will always match.

Change-Id: I134b62413a7cde25f3efda6a2452c1e3d11d41d0
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add log artifacts for upgrade steps

Context: https://trello.com/c/vJwmd6SD/771-indexing-upgrade-logs-in-logstash
         https://trello.com/c/TU3JEtmg/560-ensure-upgrade-logging

- Per feedback have added timestamper_cmd so these
  logs can be indexed by logstash.

- for clarity have added a distinct variable for update template

- for clarity have added ffu_ prefix to FFU variant of UC upgrade template

- Per feedback removed the logging from bash jinja template
  as it's inconsistent with logging norms in TQ/TQE

I suggest that we also rename undercloud_upgrade.sh.j2 to reflect
that it's used in both upgrade and update workflows, or we clearly
disambiguate and fully denormalize by duplicating the template.  In order
to limit scope/risk IMHO this should be done in a discreet commit.

Change-Id: I184c5ebd28ae11a93a854df5dc2cafd02a5e1b6c
(cherry picked from commit baff4a25229b1904e960e426208eca76c96c3ab4)

commit_message:
Add manual clean step ironic standalone test

Adds ironic standalone test to check 'erase_device_metadata'
clean-step.

Add fixes in baremetal managers to:
- do not delete ports if they do not exist
- do not delete the node if test indicates that

Co-Authored-By: Vasyl Saienko <vsaienko@mirantis.com>
Story: 1523640
Task: 20009
Depends-On: I7335638e513f066069672772ba0d9171b66ec710

Change-Id: If8d5445608c3810ad4fb344e13fcae6032dfd06c

commit_message:
Pass custom roles_data during minor update

This change adjust the templates so that the roles_data is passed
when using custom roles.

Change-Id: I3f51340df7b838c26ddab73bd39a2d4162603ab6
(cherry picked from commit a20a44d1225c947ce0e70080aa7bf063c814b0bb)

- Using lsof +D /var/log/containers should take care of (B),
  because we actually bind mount /var/log/containers only and we
  are only interested in containers log rotation. It should
  also fix (C) because we will actually manage to send the SIGHUP
  to the right containerized processes.

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5029a4b9c76268455812696290aaf82f1a0c2c23
Closes-Bug: #1776533

- Using lsof +D /var/log/containers should take care of (B),

Change-Id: I5029a4b9c76268455812696290aaf82f1a0c2c23

'}, {'created': '2018-06-13 10:01:31.000000000', 'message': 'Fix logrotate_crond issues

So currently the logrotate_crond container has a few issues issues:
A) In the postrotate it matches pids multiple times and sends SIGHUPs multiple time to processes:
    ======== /var/log/messages =====
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd" swVersion="8.24.0" x-pid="1575" x-info="http://www.rsyslog.com"] rsyslogd was HUPed
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd" swVersion="8.24.0" x-pid="1575" x-info="http://www.rsyslog.com"] rsyslogd was HUPed
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd
...

Adding sort -u in the pipeline of the postrotate script takes care of
that.

B) The logrotate_crond container should not rotate logs for services
running on the host outside of containers (i.e. rsyslog has its own
/etc/logrotate.d/rsyslog rules). Doing so violates the principle of
least surprise.

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' takes care of this as we won't
match any non containerized processes

C) The find command matches older files to be deleted but the SIGHUP is
never sent so we actually can end up in a situation where we remove a
file but the new one never gets created because the service does not get
a SIGHUP signal:

ls -la /var/log/containers/httpd/*/*
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 52046652 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 0 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/error_log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 50755274 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 4138 May 25 11:58 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:13 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/error_log

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' fixes this case as well because
now we correctly match the processes that have a deleted file that is
open and we send a proper SIGHUP to them.

Tested by doing the following:
1) Logging rotation of containerized services (B, C)
1.1) Stopped the keystone container
1.2) Made the /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log file 21M large
1.3) Started the keystone container and observed that it was logging
     correctly to /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log
1.4) Inside the logrotate_crond container we ran the following:
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
1.5) We observed correct log rotation and keystone was notified via
SIGHUP and started logging correctly:
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425 21628706 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log.1
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425      999 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log

2) No SIGHUP to host processes (A)
2.1) stopped rsyslog on the host and made one of its log files > 10M:
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 28M Jun 13 08:59 /var/log/messages
2.2) restart rsyslog
2.3) Ran the logrotation inside the container
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
2.4) Observed that no SIGHUP was sent to rsyslog on the host

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5029a4b9c76268455812696290aaf82f1a0c2c23
Closes-Bug: #1776533
'}]
commit_message:
Fix logrotate_crond issues

So currently the logrotate_crond container has a few issues issues:
A) In the postrotate it matches pids multiple times and sends SIGHUPs multiple time to processes:
    ======== /var/log/messages =====
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd" swVersion="8.24.0" x-pid="1575" x-info="http://www.rsyslog.com"] rsyslogd was HUPed
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd" swVersion="8.24.0" x-pid="1575" x-info="http://www.rsyslog.com"] rsyslogd was HUPed
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd
...

Adding sort -u in the pipeline of the postrotate script takes care of
that.

B) The logrotate_crond container should not rotate logs for services
running on the host outside of containers (i.e. rsyslog has its own
/etc/logrotate.d/rsyslog rules). Doing so violates the principle of
least surprise.

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' takes care of this as we won't
match any non containerized processes

C) The find command matches older files to be deleted but the SIGHUP is
never sent so we actually can end up in a situation where we remove a
file but the new one never gets created because the service does not get
a SIGHUP signal:

ls -la /var/log/containers/httpd/*/*
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 52046652 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 0 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/error_log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 50755274 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 4138 May 25 11:58 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:13 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/error_log

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' fixes this case as well because
now we correctly match the processes that have a deleted file that is
open and we send a proper SIGHUP to them.

Tested by doing the following:
1) Logging rotation of containerized services (B, C)
1.1) Stopped the keystone container
1.2) Made the /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log file 21M large
1.3) Started the keystone container and observed that it was logging
     correctly to /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log
1.4) Inside the logrotate_crond container we ran the following:
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
1.5) We observed correct log rotation and keystone was notified via
SIGHUP and started logging correctly:
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425 21628706 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log.1
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425      999 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log

2) No SIGHUP to host processes (A)
2.1) stopped rsyslog on the host and made one of its log files > 10M:
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 28M Jun 13 08:59 /var/log/messages
2.2) restart rsyslog
2.3) Ran the logrotation inside the container
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
2.4) Observed that no SIGHUP was sent to rsyslog on the host

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5029a4b9c76268455812696290aaf82f1a0c2c23
Closes-Bug: #1776533

commit_message:
Switch to oslo_messaging.ConfFixture.transport_url

oslo_messaging's rpc_backend setting, which is set by
ConfFixture.transport_driver has been deprecated since Newton. To allow
oslo_messaging to remove it, switch to setting transport_url instead.

Change-Id: I56ed0952f667dc51fb36aa1e85875e2d30097237
Partial-Bug: #1712399

commit_message:
update new-release to process all repositories

new-release was using the repositories tagged as part of the most
recent release to determine what to tag for the new release. This
change updates it to look at all of the repositories known to be part
of the deliverable to see which ones may need to be tagged. It tries
to report the last time a repository was tagged and still tries to
skip over repositories that do not need to be tagged because there are
no changes.

Change-Id: I23ece1220559d240f4a48818a4a3d95627e6bf40
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Fix race condition issue for k8s  multi masters
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6484, 'name': 'Feilong Wang', 'email': 'hustemb@gmail.com', 'username': 'flwang'}, {'_account_id': 20498, 'name': 'Spyros Trigazis', 'email': 'strigazi@gmail.com', 'username': 'strigazi'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22623, 'name': 'Erik Olof Gunnar Andersson', 'email': 'eandersson@blizzard.com', 'username': 'eoandersson'}, {'_account_id': 27224, 'name': 'Duc Truong', 'email': 'duc.openstack@gmail.com', 'username': 'dtruong2'}, {'_account_id': 28022, 'name': 'Bharat Kunwar', 'email': 'brtknr@bath.edu', 'username': 'brtknr'}, {'_account_id': 28411, 'name': 'Jim Bach', 'email': 'jabach@blizzard.com', 'username': 'imdigitaljim'}, {'_account_id': 28432, 'name': 'Carl Brumm', 'email': 'cbrumm@blizzard.com'}]

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2018-06-08 10:50:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28411, 'date': '2018-06-08 17:24:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

This approach will cause other complexity-related issues such as if you ever want to scale masters. I’m aware of the swarm similar design pattern but it also is an anti-pattern. What about leaving it as one resource group but adding logic on the k8s/fragments side for bootstrapping that 'primary master'.  Make a parameter out of the %index% value and write it to the heat-params file and then during the software configuration/cloud-init have a set of common master scripts but also some that run for a bootstrapping master vs a regular master.  The host can just look at the heat-param and if it is master 0 you could execute one thing and if not exit 0 and continue to the common scripts (if any). Alternatively, if the host is master 1, it can wait for some indication that master 0 has completed its work and then continue. There could be retry logic, maybe wait a few seconds between each check for the okay to continue, and maximum retries before returning a failure to heat through the wait handler so it wont have to wait until the timeout rather than reasonable time passed. The only thing here is if new hosts come up as master 0 (e.g. master 0 failed and a new one brought up) later they would need to check if the cluster is already active, should just then take the master 1 route. This particular solution is in the case of significantly divergent bootstrapping.  In the case that bootstrapping only differs here, then you don’t need the wait/retry and future master 0’s would make idempotent actions so just simply use the heat param to kubectl create -f <file> if heat-param == 0."}, {'account_id': 28411, 'date': '2018-06-08 18:53:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

A continued follow up to Magnums fix for this: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/44165

Another solution that doesn't affect the intended paradigm, and less-involved but less deterministic solution than the previous would be impose a stagger in the fragments with something like 

sleep "$((RANDOM % 10))"
kubectl apply -f <whatever>.yaml'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2018-06-09 20:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28411, 'date': '2018-06-11 18:23:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2018-06-11 18:30:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2018-06-11 21:11:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

[{'created': '2018-06-08 09:21:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix race condition issue for k8s  multi masters

'}, {'created': '2018-06-08 09:24:13.000000000', 'message': 'Fix race condition issue for k8s  multi masters

Closes-Bug: 1775759

Change-Id: I83f78022481aeef945334c37ac6c812bba9791fd
'}, {'created': '2018-06-09 20:44:17.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition issue for k8s  multi masters

Currently, when creating multi master nodes with loadbalancer,
because of the issue in kubectl[1]. One of master node will be
failed because kubectl may return AlreadyExists error due to
race condition. This patch is going to fix it by using the
index of master node to determine if it's necessary to create
resources on current master node.

[1] https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/44165

Task: 21673
Story: 1775759

Change-Id: I83f78022481aeef945334c37ac6c812bba9791fd
"}, {'created': '2018-06-13 04:21:44.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition issue for k8s  multi masters

Currently, when creating multi master nodes with loadbalancer,
because of the issue in kubectl[1]. One of master node will be
failed because kubectl may return AlreadyExists error due to
race condition. This patch is going to fix it by using the
index of master node to determine if it's necessary to create
resources on current master node.

[1] https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/44165

Task: 21673
Story: 1775759

Change-Id: I83f78022481aeef945334c37ac6c812bba9791fd
"}, {'created': '2018-06-13 17:46:07.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition issue for k8s  multi masters

When creating a multi-master cluster, all master nodes will attempt to
create kubernetes resources in the cluster, like coredns, the dashboard,
calico etc. This race conditon shouldn't be a probem when doing
declarative calls instead of imperative, (kubectl apply instead of
create). However, due to [1], kubectl fails to apply the changes and
the deployemnt scripts fail causing cluster to creation to fail in the
case of Heat SoftwareDeployments. This patch passes the ResourceGroup
index of every master so that resource creation will be attempted only
from the first master node.

[1] https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/44165

Task: 21673
Story: 1775759

Change-Id: I83f78022481aeef945334c37ac6c812bba9791fd
"}, {'created': '2018-06-13 21:17:48.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition issue for k8s  multi masters

When creating a multi-master cluster, all master nodes will attempt to
create kubernetes resources in the cluster at this same time, like
coredns, the dashboard, calico etc. This race conditon shouldn't be
a problem when doing declarative calls instead of imperative (kubectl
apply instead of create). However, due to [1], kubectl fails to apply
the changes and the deployemnt scripts fail causing cluster to creation
to fail in the case of Heat SoftwareDeployments. This patch passes the
ResourceGroup index of every master so that resource creation will be
attempted only from the first master node.

[1] https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/44165

Story: 1775759

Change-Id: I83f78022481aeef945334c37ac6c812bba9791fd
"}]
commit_message:
Fix race condition issue for k8s  multi masters

When creating a multi-master cluster, all master nodes will attempt to
create kubernetes resources in the cluster at this same time, like
coredns, the dashboard, calico etc. This race conditon shouldn't be
a problem when doing declarative calls instead of imperative (kubectl
apply instead of create). However, due to [1], kubectl fails to apply
the changes and the deployemnt scripts fail causing cluster to creation
to fail in the case of Heat SoftwareDeployments. This patch passes the
ResourceGroup index of every master so that resource creation will be
attempted only from the first master node.

[1] https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/44165

Task: 21673
Story: 1775759

Change-Id: I83f78022481aeef945334c37ac6c812bba9791fd

commit_message:
Bind internal services to internal IPs only

Some services don't need to bind on public network,
they already have an allowed network filter,
so we are binding them only to internal network:

- rabbitmq_mgmt
- nova_api_placement
- nova_api_metadata

Also disabling ssl on those since the internal vips
do not have ssl enabled by default.

Change-Id: I19705cbde61a54f96e980ba18a1bbc795ffe213e

commit_message:
objects: Add RequestSpec.requested_networks

We also need to start tracking physnet and tunneled status so we don't
have to query the neutron API multiple times for this information.

While we're here, we start passing this through from the API. This
requires a couple of mostly mechanical changes.

Part of blueprint numa-aware-vswitches

Change-Id: I0c1261a697110a38127aa0974415016699bf57bf

commit_message:
rt: Start utilizing Instance.network_requests

This is simply a case of populating the attribute and letting the code
in 'nova/virt/hardware.py' do the work.

We also removed a useless check in the 'Claim.numa_topology' property,
which checked if a value was set to False but never set said value to
True.

With this complete, we complete step three of four for the blueprint.

  [*] Identify and store affinity of networks to host NUMA nodes
  [*] Store additional information about networks requested at instance
      creation
  [*] Utilize information about host network affinity and instance
      network requests during claims
  [ ] Utilize information about host network affinity and instance
      network requests during scheduling

Part of blueprint numa-aware-vswitches

Change-Id: I78aa83ab3f6024303392f552ad9a4167b2bc0917

commit_message:
Daemonsets: Use current kubernetes daemonset api version

This PS moves to use the current ga version for kubernetes daemonsets,
additionally any remaining deployments that were using the
`extensions/v1beta1` have been updated to `apps/v1`.

Story: 2002205
Task: 21735

Change-Id: If9703162dc472af1e6096bf2b9062802fd5ce8ab
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

commit_message:
Update Release CPL doc about periodic jobs

At the weekly Glance meeting on 2018-05-17 it was agreed that the
Release CPL will monitor the periodic "tips" test jobs and report
on their status at the weekly meeting.  This patch updates the
appropriate section of the Glance Contributor's Guide.

Change-Id: Ieeab3e3a42b8197f8b0544e97748ffdb8f620f13

[{'created': '2018-06-13 20:19:58.000000000', 'message': 'Restore the order of params in ifcfg file that was inadvertently changed

This change to os-net-config in Queens changed the order of the ONBOOT
parameter in the ifcg files created by os-net-config -
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/485132/.  When upgrading a diff is done
between the existing ifcfg files and new data to write.  Since the order
is different, the ifcg files will be detected as different and interfaces,
bridges, etc. will be restarted.  Change the order back to avoid
this from happening.

Change-Id: I77162d28b1dc173e3a90cb385a3af92e21c71574
'}, {'created': '2018-06-14 00:44:58.000000000', 'message': 'Restore the order of params in ifcfg file that was inadvertently changed

This change to os-net-config in Queens changed the order of the ONBOOT
parameter in the ifcg files created by os-net-config -
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/485132/.  When upgrading a diff is done
between the existing ifcfg files and new data to write.  Since the order
is different, the ifcg files will be detected as different and interfaces,
bridges, etc. will be restarted.  Change the order back to avoid
this from happening.

Change-Id: I77162d28b1dc173e3a90cb385a3af92e21c71574
'}]
commit_message:
Restore the order of params in ifcfg file that was inadvertently changed

This change to os-net-config in Queens changed the order of the ONBOOT
parameter in the ifcg files created by os-net-config -
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/485132/.  When upgrading a diff is done
between the existing ifcfg files and new data to write.  Since the order
is different, the ifcg files will be detected as different and interfaces,
bridges, etc. will be restarted.  Change the order back to avoid
this from happening.

Change-Id: I77162d28b1dc173e3a90cb385a3af92e21c71574

commit_message:
Annotate filter parameters for tag attributes

* Add additional attributes 'tags-any', 'not-tags' and 'not-tags-any'
  to the attribute map. These three attributes represent the query
  parameters on list request.
* Add 'is_filter' keyword for attributes 'tags', 'tags-any', 'not-tags'
  and 'not-tags-any'. This indicates that these four attributes can be
  used as filter parameters. In the future, we will rely on this metadata
  to perform filter validation: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/554368/

Change-Id: I9e2033e7ba9d198f96c1ce6089a809d6721dd82d
Related-Bug: #1749820

There are several flapping tests in OSC right now - one related to
floating ips, and a set of volume tests. Turn the job to non-voting so
we don't keep blocking the ability to land things.

It's still important for SDK reviewers to look at failures here.

Change-Id: I71d2bff15e518ce7d55cd4213e85efdbf4924209
"}]
commit_message:
Turn OSC tips jobs non-voting

There are several flapping tests in OSC right now - one related to
floating ips, and a set of volume tests. Turn the job to non-voting so
we don't keep blocking the ability to land things.

It's still important for SDK reviewers to look at failures here.

Change-Id: I71d2bff15e518ce7d55cd4213e85efdbf4924209

commit_message:
Fix bug cannot create images in devstack

When launch devstack, the function for creating images such as
OpenWRT, cirros is not called. This patch will fix that bug.

Change-Id: I5f1df95b537750d03eb486e11f43cc526cbbdcf6
Closes-Bug: #1768386

subject: Don't follow symlinks when setting log permissions
messages: [{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:04:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:07:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:24:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-14 14:04:06.000000000', 'message': "Don't follow symlinks when setting log permissions

The documented default for follow is false - but ansible 2.5 seems to
have broken this for recursive file setting. We don't want to follow
symlinks here, so set follow to false directly.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/551989/
Change-Id: I858f328118a301d648bef485cc606a7fd6364ada
"}, {'created': '2018-06-14 14:07:16.000000000', 'message': "Don't follow symlinks when setting log permissions

Ansible 2.5 changed the default value of follow to true.
We don't want to follow symlinks here, so set follow to false directly.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/551989/
Change-Id: I858f328118a301d648bef485cc606a7fd6364ada
"}]
commit_message:
Don't follow symlinks when setting log permissions

Ansible 2.5 changed the default value of follow to true.
We don't want to follow symlinks here, so set follow to false directly.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/551989/
Change-Id: I858f328118a301d648bef485cc606a7fd6364ada

commit_message:
Deprecate module_plugins

An upstream change in keystone has removed the requirement to define the
module_plugins for the Mellon, Openidc and Shibboleth federation
configs.

Change-Id: I9ef488df3564f5b01ba7cf8e6a7957565858e27e
(cherry picked from commit 73f863e21ced624b5ddfac9d8e0ac5febe5c9a2d)

commit_message:
Fix docker images validation script

Set overcloud_validate_ap_services_list var and filter the pcmklatest
image out of the images used for a/p services check.

Closes-bug: 1776262

Change-Id: I28158373c7d448e909f5a090c5bf1be5450a24e0

The problem of passing different data sets to test cases is not entirely new, and probably should not justify overcomplicating tests. What if we use something like ddt instead, which we already use in ironicclient: https://github.com/openstack/python-ironicclient/blob/1ff43687c6423b617c6cda43c6a60a7bd6048626/ironicclient/tests/functional/osc/v1/test_baremetal_node_negative.py#L22-L35 ?'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-05-29 21:23:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

> The problem of passing different data sets to test cases is not

 > tests. What if we use something like ddt instead, which we already

 > ?

To me, that looks kind of magical and I don't understand how to modify that without spending time digging. I kind of like the more explicit "looks more complicated" or "repeated" test style as a result. Others thoughts?

Dropping my vote to +1 to encourage discussion since the -1 effectively blocks merging.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-06-06 11:15:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-06-06 11:16:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Adds more `ipmitool` errors as retryable

This change extends the list of `ipmitool` errors that
ironic treats as retryable on failure.

Change-Id: I5fddc95404a1725f03bd26da51932c3ece5a5a35
Story: 2001989
Task: 19611

[{'created': '2018-06-14 13:54:44.000000000', 'message': "Vault version in snap store may not start with 'v'

The nagios check that checks the snap store version matches the
deployed assumes that the version info in the snap store starts
a 'v'. If it doesn't it return None. This fixes that.

Change-Id: I89f56866c78b286e7d07b43432d56aa41a0c2eb9

commit_message:
Vault version in snap store may not start with 'v'

The nagios check that checks the snap store version matches the
deployed assumes that the version info in the snap store starts
a 'v'. If it doesn't it return None. This fixes that.

Change-Id: I89f56866c78b286e7d07b43432d56aa41a0c2eb9

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/56/518856/1/check/legacy-tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario001-multinode-oooq-container/a4028aa/logs/subnode-2/var/log/cinder/"}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2017-11-27 10:06:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2017-11-27 10:11:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

IMO there is no good reason not to have containerized cinder in stable/pike, it just seems to me we forgot to backport Ied8429be0eb16e4d775d1dfe0c2f0f31f9e01e23. Let's see if the CI succeeds this time and let's make a decision whether or not to enable containerized cinder in stable/pike."}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-11-27 14:17:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > Hmm, cinder services weren't containerized (by default) in pike,

 > > I'm not sure this patch is warranted. Note in [1] the logs show

 >

 > stable/pike, it just seems to me we forgot to backport

 > succeeds this time and let's make a decision whether or not to
 > enable containerized cinder in stable/pike.

My earlier concern about this patch was based on the current pike code, in which cinder is not containerized. If containerized cinder is backported to stable/pike [1] then I would approve this patch as well.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/523076"}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Containerize cinder services under pacemaker in CI

This patch fixes a timing issue with cinder's db sync when
cinder-manage is containerized but cinder-volume is not.

Cinder services were containerized in [1], and this patch updates
the CI jobs so cinder-volume and cinder-backup with pacemaker are
also containerized.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/479001

Change-Id: Ic20af8a9bb24c4d21d1fd71bc65b001aa9c09c7c
Closes-Bug: #1729253
Closes-Bug: #1729339
(cherry picked from commit 17d34888958c892cbf8fda6ef89e323ed1075076)

new pip version 10 changed a Warning into an Error: When calling "pip

in master to cherry-pick this from. Newer branches use a different way
to set up the tox environment.

commit_message:
Fix sphinx docs job on stable/pike

It looks like the CLIENT_NAME env variable is not passed onto the
script when running the tox job.

Also include the fix from I35e9ede7103031ea3ea45e35d743e63059fb8d0b:

build-openstack-sphinx-docs jobs fail on stable branches because the
new pip version 10 changed a Warning into an Error: When calling "pip
install" without any package name, the command now
fails. tox_install.sh is being called during docs job without any
package passed to pip.

Note that this only affects stable/pike and older, so there is no patch
in master to cherry-pick this from. Newer branches use a different way
to set up the tox environment.

Change-Id: I8b413799fd3d1c84a6a27222641267b4abad5651

subject: Do not apply format expansions to passwords
messages: [{'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2018-06-11 12:52:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2018-06-14 10:34:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-06-14 12:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-11 12:52:21.000000000', 'message': 'Do not apply format expansions to passwords

get_one_cloud() and get_one_cloud_osc() iterate over config
values and try to expand any variables in those values by
calling value.format(), however some config values
(e.g. password) should never have format() applied to them, not
only might that change the password but it will also cause the
format() function to raise an exception if it can not parse the
format string. Examples would be single brace (e.g. 'foo{')
which raises an ValueError because it's looking for a matching
end brace or a brace pair with a key value that cannot be found
(e.g. 'foo{bar}') which raises a KeyError.

It is not reasonsable to try to escape any braces because:

1) Escaping all braces breaks valid use of the format string syntax.

2) Trying to determine exactly which braces should be escaped and
which should be preserved is a daunting task and likely would not be
robust.

3) Some strings might look like valid format syntax but still should
be escaped (e.g. "foo{bar}", if this appeared in a password we
wouldn't escape it and there would be a key error on the 'bar' key.

4) In general passwords should never be modified, you never want to
apply formatting to them.

The right approach is to maintain a list of config values which are
excluded from having formatting applied to them. At the moment that
list just includes 'password' but perhaps down the road other
exceptions might crop up. This patch follows this approach,
the list of excluded values can easily be updated if others are
discovered.

Change-Id: I187bdec582d4c2cc6c7fda47a1538194137c616b
Closes-Bug: 1635696
Signed-off-by: John Dennis <jdennis@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit c7243f1747b679c6bc4df8aead8133ec25898182)
'}, {'created': '2018-06-14 10:34:42.000000000', 'message': 'Do not apply format expansions to passwords

get_one_cloud() and get_one_cloud_osc() iterate over config
values and try to expand any variables in those values by
calling value.format(), however some config values
(e.g. password) should never have format() applied to them, not
only might that change the password but it will also cause the
format() function to raise an exception if it can not parse the
format string. Examples would be single brace (e.g. 'foo{')
which raises an ValueError because it's looking for a matching
end brace or a brace pair with a key value that cannot be found
(e.g. 'foo{bar}') which raises a KeyError.

It is not reasonsable to try to escape any braces because:

1) Escaping all braces breaks valid use of the format string syntax.

2) Trying to determine exactly which braces should be escaped and
which should be preserved is a daunting task and likely would not be
robust.

3) Some strings might look like valid format syntax but still should
be escaped (e.g. "foo{bar}", if this appeared in a password we
wouldn't escape it and there would be a key error on the 'bar' key.

4) In general passwords should never be modified, you never want to
apply formatting to them.

The right approach is to maintain a list of config values which are
excluded from having formatting applied to them. At the moment that
list just includes 'password' but perhaps down the road other
exceptions might crop up. This patch follows this approach,
the list of excluded values can easily be updated if others are
discovered.

Change-Id: I187bdec582d4c2cc6c7fda47a1538194137c616b
Closes-Bug: 1635696
Signed-off-by: John Dennis <jdennis@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit c7243f1747b679c6bc4df8aead8133ec25898182)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not apply format expansions to passwords

get_one_cloud() and get_one_cloud_osc() iterate over config
values and try to expand any variables in those values by
calling value.format(), however some config values
(e.g. password) should never have format() applied to them, not
only might that change the password but it will also cause the
format() function to raise an exception if it can not parse the
format string. Examples would be single brace (e.g. 'foo{')
which raises an ValueError because it's looking for a matching
end brace or a brace pair with a key value that cannot be found
(e.g. 'foo{bar}') which raises a KeyError.

It is not reasonsable to try to escape any braces because:

1) Escaping all braces breaks valid use of the format string syntax.

2) Trying to determine exactly which braces should be escaped and
which should be preserved is a daunting task and likely would not be
robust.

3) Some strings might look like valid format syntax but still should
be escaped (e.g. "foo{bar}", if this appeared in a password we
wouldn't escape it and there would be a key error on the 'bar' key.

4) In general passwords should never be modified, you never want to
apply formatting to them.

The right approach is to maintain a list of config values which are
excluded from having formatting applied to them. At the moment that
list just includes 'password' but perhaps down the road other
exceptions might crop up. This patch follows this approach,
the list of excluded values can easily be updated if others are
discovered.

Change-Id: I187bdec582d4c2cc6c7fda47a1538194137c616b
Closes-Bug: 1635696
Signed-off-by: John Dennis <jdennis@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit c7243f1747b679c6bc4df8aead8133ec25898182)

+1

Change-Id: I37600d19adb5e8e83ac32031532d327defe68369

[{'created': '2018-05-31 19:16:30.000000000', 'message': 'Cap VirtualInterfacesTestJSON at Queens

Nova is working on removing the nova-network only
compute REST APIs in the Rocky release, which means
any requests to those APIs after Queens will result
in a 410 response, regardless of microversion or
whether or not neutron is being used.

The os-virtual-interfaces API is being removed in
nova change: https://review.openstack.org/569923/

As a result, VirtualInterfacesTestJSON no longer
works against Rocky+ versions of nova.

This change caps the max_microversion on the test
to 2.60 which was the highest microversion for the
compute REST API in Queens.

Related to blueprint remove-nova-network

Change-Id: I7aea99d7c1818b8edcda41ba4eaa062a8ea069eb
'}, {'created': '2018-06-06 20:45:15.000000000', 'message': 'Add config option to skip nova-network compute API tests

Nova is working on removing the nova-network only
compute REST APIs in the Rocky release, which means
any requests to those APIs after Queens will result
in a 410 response, regardless of microversion or
whether or not neutron is being used.

The os-virtual-interfaces API is being removed in
nova change: https://review.openstack.org/569923/

As a result, os-virtual-interfaces tests will no longer
works against Rocky+ versions of nova.

This change adds a new configuration option,
[compute-feature-enabled]/nova_network, which can
be used to skip nova-network specific compute API
tests. Note that this is checked in some cases even
if neutron is being used, because Tempest still performs
negative testing of the nova-network APIs.

An alternative to this new config option would be to
perform some kind of version discovery in the base
compute API test to determine if the compute API is
at the point where the nova-network APIs are gone
and related tests should be skipped.

Related to blueprint remove-nova-network

Change-Id: I7aea99d7c1818b8edcda41ba4eaa062a8ea069eb

commit_message:
Cap nova-network tests at Queens

Nova is working on removing the nova-network only
compute REST APIs in the Rocky release, which means
any requests to those APIs after Queens will result
in a 410 response, regardless of microversion or
whether or not neutron is being used.

The os-virtual-interfaces API is being removed in
nova change: https://review.openstack.org/569923/

As a result, os-virtual-interfaces tests will no longer
works against Rocky+ versions of nova.

This adds a new check in the base compute API test
class to determine, based on the max compute API
microversion, which release is being tested and if
Rocky+ the nova-network specific tests will be skipped.

Subsequent nova-network specific tests will be skipped
as the API removal changes are proposed in nova.

Related to blueprint remove-nova-network

Change-Id: I7aea99d7c1818b8edcda41ba4eaa062a8ea069eb

commit_message:
Fix database creation tasks

The previous patch [1] did not use the correct jinja
templating for the variables.  In addition, the permissions
are not appended to so they get reset on every iteration.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/571785

Change-Id: I10b900727ef7b116aad8e4184538d827bb9cf21e

Closes-Bug: #1776474

commit_message:
Use UpgradeInitCommonCommand with deployed-server too

We've hit an issue in multinode CI that Ansible wasn't getting updated
during `upgrade prepare`. UpgradeInitCommonCommand wasn't being
executed because it was left out from deployed-server.yaml.

Change-Id: I940c3e05944829a6a4155722181e5fa85a963660
Closes-Bug: #1776474

'}]
commit_message:
Django 2.0 support and fix lower-constraints tox env

Replace django.core.urlresolves with django.urls

(In Django 2.0) The django.core.urlresolvers module is removed
in favor of its new location, django.urls.
It was deprecated in Django 1.10:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/releases/1.10/#id3

Add py35dj20 job to test Django 2.0 integration.
And update the lower-constraints.

Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ellen Batbouta <ellen.batbouta@oracle.com>

Change-Id: I3456162c934eb48ccf180d80b5cf7ff5614221c0

commit_message:
Split heat stack creation in modules

This commit splits the heat stack validation in three phases: the
creation, the check and the deletion. In this way it will be more usable
for different purposes.

Change-Id: I7010b27b2762dce67702db0561380442d6ac2575

commit_message:
Add IPv6 support

Adds support for running ceilometer on an IPv6
network. An new config options prefer-ipv6 is
provided which, when set to True, will instruct
the charm to use IPv6 for all networking.

Change-Id: If5609a934dde9a0510f65cea800ba4495d882db1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-02 16:44:58.000000000', 'message': "Modernize VIRT_DRIVER=fake usage

This makes three changes:

1. The quota options set when using the fake
   virt driver have been renamed so we're getting
   deprecation warnings on using the old names.
   Rather than set each quota limit value individually,
   we can just use the noop quota driver for the same
   effect.

2. The enabled_filters list for the scheduler was last
   updated when using the fake virt driver back in Juno
   via Ic7ec87e4d497d9db58eec93f2b304fe9770a2bbc - with
   the Placement service, we don't need the CoreFilter,
   RamFilter or DiskFilter. Also, in general, we just
   don't need to hard-code a list of scheduler filters
   when using the fake virt driver. If one needs to set
   their own scheduler filter list, they can do so using
   the $FILTERS variable (or post-config for nova.conf).

3. The largeops job, which ran the Tempest scenario tests,
   has been gone for a few years now, as have the Tempest
   scenario tests, so the API_WORKERS modification when
   using the fake virt driver should be removed. If we had
   a CI job like the largeops job today, we would set the
   worker config via the job rather than in devstack.

Change-Id: I8d2bb2af40b5db8a555482a0852b1604aec29f15
"}]
commit_message:
Modernize VIRT_DRIVER=fake usage

This makes three changes:

1. The quota options set when using the fake
   virt driver have been renamed so we're getting
   deprecation warnings on using the old names.
   Rather than set each quota limit value individually,
   we can just use the noop quota driver for the same
   effect.

2. The enabled_filters list for the scheduler was last
   updated when using the fake virt driver back in Juno
   via Ic7ec87e4d497d9db58eec93f2b304fe9770a2bbc - with
   the Placement service, we don't need the CoreFilter,
   RamFilter or DiskFilter. Also, in general, we just
   don't need to hard-code a list of scheduler filters
   when using the fake virt driver. If one needs to set
   their own scheduler filter list, they can do so using
   the $FILTERS variable (or post-config for nova.conf).

3. The largeops job, which ran the Tempest scenario tests,
   has been gone for a few years now, as have the Tempest
   scenario tests, so the API_WORKERS modification when
   using the fake virt driver should be removed. If we had
   a CI job like the largeops job today, we would set the
   worker config via the job rather than in devstack.

Change-Id: I8d2bb2af40b5db8a555482a0852b1604aec29f15

With change I7e1e89cd66397883453935dcf7172d977bf82e84 the placement
service may optionally use its own database. In order for this to
work, however, the ordering of how both nova and placement are
configured and initialized in stack.sh requires careful control.

* nova.conf must be created first
* then placement must make some adjustments to it
* then lib/placement needs to create the placement database
* before nova does a database sync

Otherwise, when the placement_database/connection is defined, the nova
db_sync command will fail because the placement database does not yet
